_link.title: I can explain the difference between cations and anions

toLevel2.question: What is a cation?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: A cation is an ion that has lost electrons and therefore has a positive charge.

distractors.explanation: A negatively charged ion is called an anion, not a cation.
A neutral atom has no charge. Cations are positively charged.
Neutrons do not affect charge. Cations are formed by losing electrons.

toLevel2.question: What is an anion?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: An anion is an ion that has gained electrons and therefore has a negative charge.

distractors.explanation: A positively charged ion is a cation, not an anion.
Anions carry a negative charge; they are not uncharged.

distractors.answer: An atom that has lost neutrons
distractors.explanation: Neutrons are not involved in ion formation. Anions gain electrons.

toLevel2.question: How is a cation formed?
toLevel2.correct: An atom loses one or more electrons
toLevel2.correctExplanation: When an atom loses electrons, it has more protons than electrons, giving it a positive charge (cation).

distractors.answer: An atom gains one or more electrons
distractors.explanation: Gaining electrons forms a negatively charged anion, not a cation.

distractors.answer: An atom gains one or more protons
distractors.explanation: Protons are not gained or lost in chemical reactions.

distractors.answer: An atom loses one or more protons
distractors.explanation: Protons are not lost in chemical reactions. Ions are formed by electron transfer.

toLevel2.question: Which type of element typically forms cations?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Metals have few outer electrons and tend to lose them to form positively charged cations.

distractors.explanation: Non-metals typically gain electrons to form anions, not cations.
Noble gases have full outer shells and rarely form ions.
Metalloids can go either way, but metals are the typical cation-forming elements.

toLevel2.question: Which type of element typically forms anions?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Non-metals have nearly full outer shells and tend to gain electrons to form negatively charged anions.

distractors.explanation: Metals lose electrons to form cations, not anions.
Noble gases have full outer shells and rarely form ions.
Transition metals form cations, not anions.

toLevel2.sentence: A cation is a {{blank:1}} charged ion formed when an atom {{blank:2}} electrons.

blanks.correctExplanation: Losing electrons leaves more protons than electrons, creating a positive charge.

distractors.explanation: Negative charge results from gaining electrons, forming an anion, not a cation.
Ions always carry a charge; they cannot be neutral.

blanks.correctExplanation: Cations are formed when atoms lose one or more electrons.

distractors.explanation: Gaining electrons forms anions, not cations.
Sharing electrons occurs in covalent bonding, not ion formation.

toLevel2.sentence: An anion is formed when a {{blank:1}} atom {{blank:2}} electrons to fill its outer shell.

blanks.correctExplanation: Non-metals gain electrons to achieve a full outer shell, forming anions.

distractors.explanation: Metals lose electrons to form cations, not anions.
Noble gases already have full outer shells and do not typically form ions.

blanks.correctExplanation: Gaining electrons gives the atom more electrons than protons, creating a negative charge.

distractors.explanation: Losing electrons would form a positive cation, not a negative anion.
Electrons cannot be destroyed in chemical reactions.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the sentence about ion charges.
toLevel2.sentence: Na⁺ is a {{blank:1}} and Cl⁻ is an {{blank:2}}.

blanks.correctExplanation: Na⁺ has a positive charge, making it a cation.

distractors.explanation: Anions are negative. Na⁺ is positive, so it is a cation.
Na⁺ is an ion, not a molecule.

blanks.correctExplanation: Cl⁻ has a negative charge, making it an anion.

distractors.explanation: Cations are positive. Cl⁻ is negative, so it is an anion.
Isotopes differ in neutron count. Cl⁻ is a charged ion, not an isotope.

toLevel2.question: Metals form anions by gaining electrons.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Metals form cations by losing electrons, not anions. Anions are formed by non-metals gaining electrons.

distractors.explanation: Metals lose electrons to form positively charged cations. Non-metals gain electrons to form anions.

toLevel2.question: A chloride ion (Cl⁻) is an example of an anion.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Cl⁻ has a negative charge because it gained one electron, making it an anion.

distractors.explanation: Cl⁻ is negatively charged and is therefore an anion by definition.

toLevel3.question: A sodium atom has 11 protons and 11 electrons. When it forms Na⁺, how many electrons does it have?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Sodium loses 1 electron to form Na⁺, going from 11 electrons to 10.

distractors.explanation: 11 electrons would make it neutral. Na⁺ has lost 1 electron.
Gaining an electron would form Na⁻, not Na⁺.
The question asks about electrons. The proton count stays at 11.

toLevel3.question: Why does chlorine form a Cl⁻ ion rather than a Cl⁺ ion?
toLevel3.correct: Chlorine has 7 outer electrons and gains 1 to achieve a full outer shell
toLevel3.correctExplanation: With 7 outer electrons, chlorine only needs to gain 1 electron to fill its outer shell. Losing 7 electrons would require much more energy.

distractors.answer: Chlorine has 1 outer electron and loses it easily
distractors.explanation: Chlorine has 7 outer electrons, not 1. It gains 1 electron, not loses.

distractors.answer: Chlorine is a metal and metals always form negative ions
distractors.explanation: Chlorine is a non-metal. Metals form positive ions, not negative ones.

distractors.answer: Chlorine has no outer electrons so it must gain some
distractors.explanation: Chlorine has 7 outer electrons. It gains 1 more to reach 8.

toLevel3.question: Why do Group 2 metals form 2+ cations?
toLevel3.correct: They have 2 outer electrons that they lose to achieve a stable electron configuration
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Group 2 metals have 2 outer electrons. Losing both achieves the stable configuration of the nearest noble gas, forming a 2+ ion.

distractors.answer: They gain 2 electrons to fill their outer shell
distractors.explanation: Metals lose electrons, not gain them. Gaining 2 electrons would form a 2− anion.

distractors.answer: They have 2 protons that they transfer to other atoms
distractors.explanation: Protons are never transferred in chemical reactions. Only electrons are transferred.

distractors.answer: They share 2 electrons with non-metal atoms
distractors.explanation: Sharing electrons is covalent bonding. Ionic bonding involves transferring electrons.

toLevel3.question: An oxide ion has the formula O²⁻. How was this ion formed?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Oxygen has 6 outer electrons and gains 2 to fill its outer shell (reaching 8), giving it a 2− charge.

distractors.explanation: Losing electrons would form a positive ion (O²⁺), not a negative one.
Gaining protons would change the element. Ion formation involves electron transfer only.
Losing protons would change the element. Chemical reactions do not alter proton counts.

toLevel3.question: What is the connection between an atom's position in the periodic table and whether it forms a cation or anion?
toLevel3.correct: Elements on the left (metals) form cations; elements on the right (non-metals) form anions
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Metals (left side) have few outer electrons to lose, forming cations. Non-metals (right side) need few electrons to fill their shell, forming anions.

distractors.answer: Elements on the left form anions; elements on the right form cations
distractors.explanation: This is reversed. Metals (left) form cations and non-metals (right) form anions.

distractors.answer: All elements form cations regardless of position
distractors.explanation: Non-metals form anions, not cations.

distractors.answer: The periodic table position has no relationship to ion formation
distractors.explanation: Position directly relates to outer electrons, which determines whether cations or anions form.

toLevel3.question: A calcium ion is written as Ca²⁺. What does the 2+ tell you?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A 2+ charge means 2 more protons than electrons. The atom lost 2 electrons to form this cation.

distractors.explanation: Gaining electrons would produce a negative charge, not 2+.
Calcium has 20 protons. The 2+ refers to the charge from losing 2 electrons.
Neutrons do not affect charge. The 2+ refers to losing 2 electrons.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about ion formation.
toLevel3.sentence: When a sodium atom loses 1 electron, it forms a Na⁺ {{blank:1}} because it now has more {{blank:2}} than electrons.

blanks.correctExplanation: A positively charged ion is called a cation.

distractors.explanation: An anion is negatively charged. Na⁺ is positive, so it is a cation.
Isotopes differ in neutrons. Na⁺ is a charged ion.

blanks.correctExplanation: After losing an electron, there are 11 protons but only 10 electrons, giving a net positive charge.

distractors.explanation: Neutrons are uncharged and do not contribute to the ion's charge.
Having more electrons than protons would give a negative charge, not positive.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about oxide ions.
toLevel3.sentence: An oxygen atom (2, 6) gains {{blank:1}} electrons to form an O²⁻ {{blank:2}}.

blanks.correctExplanation: Oxygen needs 2 more electrons to fill its outer shell from 6 to 8.

distractors.explanation: 6 is the number of outer electrons oxygen already has, not the number it gains.
8 is the target for a full outer shell. Oxygen gains 2 to get from 6 to 8.

blanks.correctExplanation: A negatively charged ion is called an anion.

distractors.explanation: A cation is positive. O²⁻ is negative, making it an anion.
O²⁻ is an ion, not a molecule.

toLevel3.sentence: To remember the difference: {{blank:1}} are positive (think: cats are paws-itive) and {{blank:2}} are negative.

blanks.correctExplanation: Cations are positively charged ions.

distractors.explanation: Anions are negative, not positive.
Neutrons are uncharged subatomic particles, not ions.

blanks.correctExplanation: Anions are negatively charged ions.

distractors.explanation: Cations are positive, not negative.
Protons are positive subatomic particles, not negative ions.

toLevel3.question: A fluoride ion (F⁻) has more electrons than protons.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: F⁻ has 9 protons and 10 electrons (gained 1). More electrons than protons gives a negative charge.

distractors.explanation: F⁻ gained an electron, giving it 10 electrons vs 9 protons. It does have more electrons than protons.

toLevel4.question: A magnesium atom (2, 8, 2) reacts with an oxygen atom (2, 6). Describe the ion formation that occurs.
toLevel4.correct: Mg loses 2 electrons to form Mg²⁺; O gains 2 electrons to form O²⁻
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Magnesium transfers its 2 outer electrons to oxygen. Both achieve stable noble gas configurations.

distractors.answer: Mg gains 2 electrons to form Mg²⁻; O loses 2 electrons to form O²⁺
distractors.explanation: Metals lose electrons (forming cations) and non-metals gain electrons (forming anions), not the reverse.

distractors.answer: Both atoms share 2 electrons to form a covalent bond
distractors.explanation: Magnesium and oxygen form an ionic bond through electron transfer, not a covalent bond.

distractors.answer: Mg loses 6 electrons to form Mg⁶⁺; O gains 6 electrons to form O⁶⁻
distractors.explanation: Magnesium only loses its 2 outer electrons. Oxygen only gains 2 to fill its outer shell.

toLevel4.question: A student writes that Na⁺ has 11 protons and 11 electrons. Identify and correct the error.
toLevel4.correct: Na⁺ has 11 protons and 10 electrons; it lost 1 electron
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The + charge means sodium lost an electron. It still has 11 protons but now only 10 electrons.

distractors.explanation: The number of protons never changes. Sodium always has 11 protons.
12 electrons would give Na a 1− charge, not 1+.

distractors.answer: The student is correct; Na⁺ has equal protons and electrons
distractors.explanation: Equal protons and electrons would mean no charge. Na⁺ has a positive charge from losing 1 electron.

toLevel4.question: Predict the ion formed by aluminium (2, 8, 3) and explain your reasoning.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Aluminium has 3 outer electrons. It loses all 3 to achieve the stable electron configuration of neon (2, 8), forming Al³⁺.

distractors.explanation: Aluminium is a metal and loses electrons to form a cation, not gains electrons to form an anion.
Aluminium only loses its 3 outer electrons, not 5.
Aluminium loses only its 3 outer electrons. Removing inner shell electrons requires enormous energy.

toLevel4.question: In the compound calcium chloride, calcium forms Ca²⁺ and chlorine forms Cl⁻. Why are two chloride ions needed per calcium ion?
toLevel4.correct: Ca²⁺ has a 2+ charge that must be balanced by two 1− chloride ions
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The overall compound must be electrically neutral. Two Cl⁻ ions (total 2−) balance one Ca²⁺ ion (2+), giving CaCl₂.

distractors.answer: Calcium needs to share 2 electrons with chlorine
distractors.explanation: This is ionic bonding (electron transfer), not covalent bonding (electron sharing).

distractors.answer: Each chloride ion can only bond to half a calcium ion
distractors.explanation: Ions are whole particles. The 2:1 ratio is due to charge balance, not partial bonding.

distractors.answer: Chlorine atoms always come in pairs
distractors.explanation: Cl₂ molecules come in pairs, but chloride ions are independent. The ratio is about charge balance.

toLevel4.question: An atom has 16 protons and 18 electrons. Identify this species.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: 16 protons = sulfur. 18 electrons − 16 protons = 2 extra electrons, giving a 2− charge. This is S²⁻.

distractors.explanation: More electrons than protons gives a negative charge, not positive.
18 electrons with 16 protons is not argon (which has 18 protons). The element is determined by protons.
16 protons identifies the element as sulfur, not oxygen (which has 8 protons).

toLevel4.question: Explain why a sodium ion (Na⁺) is smaller than a sodium atom, while a chloride ion (Cl⁻) is larger than a chlorine atom.
toLevel4.correct: Na⁺ lost an electron shell; Cl⁻ gained an electron, increasing electron repulsion
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Na loses its only outer electron, removing the third shell entirely and making the ion smaller. Cl gains an electron, increasing electron-electron repulsion and making the ion larger.

distractors.answer: Na⁺ gained a proton; Cl⁻ lost a proton
distractors.explanation: Protons do not change during ion formation. Only electrons are transferred.

distractors.answer: Both ions are the same size as their atoms
distractors.explanation: Ion formation changes the electron count, which changes the size.

distractors.answer: Na⁺ is larger because it has more charge; Cl⁻ is smaller because negative charge contracts
distractors.explanation: Na⁺ is actually smaller (lost a shell) and Cl⁻ is larger (increased repulsion).

toLevel4.question: During electrolysis of molten sodium chloride, Na⁺ ions move to the negative electrode and Cl⁻ ions move to the positive electrode. Explain why.
toLevel4.correct: Opposite charges attract: cations move to the negative cathode, anions to the positive anode
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Positive Na⁺ cations are attracted to the negative electrode (cathode) and negative Cl⁻ anions are attracted to the positive electrode (anode).

distractors.answer: Like charges attract: cations go to the positive electrode
distractors.explanation: Like charges repel. Opposite charges attract, so cations go to the negative electrode.

distractors.answer: Both ions move to the same electrode
distractors.explanation: Oppositely charged ions move to opposite electrodes.

distractors.answer: The ions do not move; only electrons move through the liquid
distractors.explanation: In molten ionic compounds, mobile ions carry the current by moving to opposite electrodes.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence about ion formation in MgO.
toLevel4.sentence: Magnesium loses {{blank:1}} electrons to form a Mg²⁺ {{blank:2}}, and oxygen gains {{blank:3}} electrons to form an O²⁻ anion.

blanks.correctExplanation: Magnesium has 2 outer electrons and loses both to form Mg²⁺.

distractors.explanation: 8 is the number of electrons in the second shell. Magnesium loses its 2 outer electrons.
Oxygen has 6 outer electrons. Magnesium has 2.

blanks.correctExplanation: Mg²⁺ is positively charged, making it a cation.

distractors.explanation: Anions are negative. Mg²⁺ is positive, so it is a cation.
Mg²⁺ is a charged ion, not a neutral atom.

blanks.correctExplanation: Oxygen has 6 outer electrons and gains 2 to fill its outer shell to 8.

distractors.explanation: 6 is the number of outer electrons oxygen already has, not the number gained.
8 is the target for a full shell. Oxygen gains 2 to reach it.

toLevel4.sentence: During electrolysis, cations move to the {{blank:1}} electrode and anions move to the {{blank:2}} electrode.

blanks.correctExplanation: Positive cations are attracted to the negative electrode (cathode).

distractors.explanation: Cations are positive and are attracted to the opposite (negative) electrode.
Electrodes in electrolysis are charged, not neutral.

blanks.correctExplanation: Negative anions are attracted to the positive electrode (anode).

distractors.explanation: Anions are negative and are attracted to the opposite (positive) electrode.
Electrodes in electrolysis are charged, not neutral.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence about ion sizes.
toLevel4.sentence: Cations are {{blank:1}} than their parent atoms because they have {{blank:2}} electrons.

blanks.correctExplanation: Losing electrons reduces electron-electron repulsion and may remove an entire shell, making the ion smaller.

distractors.explanation: Losing electrons makes the ion smaller, not larger.
Removing electrons does change the size of the species.

blanks.correctExplanation: Cations have lost electrons, so they have fewer electrons than the neutral atom.

distractors.explanation: Cations have lost electrons, giving them fewer, not more.
Cations have lost electrons, so the count is different.

toLevel5.question: Na⁺ and F⁻ are isoelectronic (both have 10 electrons). However, Na⁺ is smaller than F⁻. Explain why.
toLevel5.correct: Na⁺ has 11 protons pulling on 10 electrons, while F⁻ has only 9 protons pulling on 10 electrons
toLevel5.correctExplanation: More protons relative to electrons means a stronger nuclear pull, drawing the electron cloud in tighter. Na⁺ (11p, 10e) is smaller than F⁻ (9p, 10e).

distractors.answer: Na⁺ has more electron shells than F⁻
distractors.explanation: Both have the same electron configuration (2, 8). The difference is in the nuclear charge.

distractors.answer: F⁻ has more protons, so it holds electrons less tightly
distractors.explanation: F⁻ has fewer protons (9) than Na⁺ (11). Fewer protons means less pull on the same electrons.

distractors.answer: They are actually the same size because they have the same electrons
distractors.explanation: Same electron count does not mean same size. The different nuclear charges cause different sizes.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that since protons are positive and cations are positive, cations must have gained protons. Evaluate this reasoning.
toLevel5.correct: The reasoning is wrong; cations are positive because they lost electrons, not gained protons
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Protons are never gained or lost in chemical reactions. The positive charge on a cation results from having fewer electrons than protons after electron loss.

distractors.answer: The reasoning is correct; cations do gain protons
distractors.explanation: Protons are fixed in the nucleus. Chemical reactions only transfer electrons.

distractors.answer: The reasoning is partially correct; both proton gain and electron loss occur
distractors.explanation: Only electron transfer occurs in ion formation. Proton counts never change.

distractors.answer: The reasoning is wrong; cations are actually negative
distractors.explanation: Cations are indeed positive, but because of electron loss, not proton gain.

toLevel5.question: Transition metals can form cations with different charges (e.g., Fe²⁺ and Fe³⁺). Why can iron form both 2+ and 3+ ions, unlike main group metals?
toLevel5.correct: Iron can lose variable numbers of electrons from both its outer and inner d-orbitals
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Transition metals have electrons in both outer s and inner d subshells with similar energies, allowing variable numbers of electrons to be lost.

distractors.answer: Iron can gain different numbers of protons
distractors.explanation: Protons are never gained in chemical reactions. Variable charges come from variable electron loss.

distractors.answer: Iron always loses the same number of electrons; the charge varies randomly
distractors.explanation: The charge depends on how many electrons are lost, which varies depending on the reaction.

distractors.answer: Main group metals can also form variable charges just as easily
distractors.explanation: Main group metals typically form only one charge because they lose all outer electrons to reach a noble gas configuration.

toLevel5.question: In a crystal of NaCl, each Na⁺ is surrounded by 6 Cl⁻ ions and each Cl⁻ by 6 Na⁺ ions. Explain why this arrangement maximises stability.
toLevel5.correct: Each ion is surrounded by oppositely charged ions, maximising attractive forces and minimising repulsive forces
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The alternating arrangement ensures each ion has maximum attraction to its neighbours while keeping same-charge ions apart, giving the lowest energy (most stable) structure.

distractors.answer: Each ion touches as many same-charge ions as possible
distractors.explanation: Same-charge ions repel each other. The structure minimises contact between like charges.

distractors.answer: The arrangement is random and has no effect on stability
distractors.explanation: The lattice is highly ordered specifically to maximise stability.

distractors.answer: Only the cations contribute to stability; the anions are passive
distractors.explanation: Both cations and anions contribute to the electrostatic interactions equally.

toLevel5.question: Polyatomic ions like sulfate (SO₄²⁻) contain covalent bonds within the ion but form ionic compounds. Explain how an anion can contain covalent bonds.
toLevel5.correct: The atoms within the ion share electrons covalently, but the overall ion carries a charge and bonds ionically with cations
toLevel5.correctExplanation: S and O atoms share electrons (covalent bonds) within the sulfate ion. The ion as a whole has a 2− charge and forms ionic bonds with cations like Na⁺.

distractors.answer: Polyatomic ions have only ionic bonds throughout
distractors.explanation: The bonds between S and O within the sulfate ion are covalent, not ionic.

distractors.answer: Polyatomic ions have only covalent bonds and cannot form ionic compounds
distractors.explanation: The ion as a whole carries a charge and forms ionic bonds with oppositely charged ions.

distractors.answer: Sulfate is not really an ion because it contains multiple atoms
distractors.explanation: Polyatomic ions are genuine ions. Having multiple atoms does not prevent them from carrying a charge.

toLevel5.question: Explain why the first ionisation energy of sodium is much lower than the second ionisation energy, and relate this to why sodium forms Na⁺ and not Na²⁺.
toLevel5.correct: Removing the first electron breaks into the outer shell, but the second requires breaking into the stable inner shell
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Sodium's first electron is in the outer third shell and easy to remove. The second electron is in the inner second shell (noble gas core) and requires enormously more energy.

distractors.answer: Both ionisation energies are similar, but Na²⁺ is unstable
distractors.explanation: The second ionisation energy is dramatically higher, not similar. This is why Na²⁺ does not form.

distractors.answer: Sodium has only 1 electron total, so Na²⁺ is impossible
distractors.explanation: Sodium has 11 electrons. It could theoretically lose more, but the energy required is prohibitive.

distractors.answer: The second ionisation energy is lower, but Na prefers 1+ for symmetry
distractors.explanation: The second ionisation energy is much higher, not lower. Ion formation is about energy, not symmetry.

toLevel5.question: Oxide (O²⁻) and fluoride (F⁻) ions are isoelectronic with neon. Compare their sizes and explain the trend.
toLevel5.correct: O²⁻ is largest, then F⁻, then Ne, because fewer protons relative to electrons means less pull on the electron cloud
toLevel5.correctExplanation: All have 10 electrons, but O²⁻ has 8 protons, F⁻ has 9, and Ne has 10. Less nuclear charge per electron means a larger electron cloud.

distractors.answer: All three are the same size because they have identical electron configurations
distractors.explanation: Same electron count but different nuclear charges gives different sizes.

distractors.answer: Ne is largest because it has the most protons
distractors.explanation: More protons pull the electron cloud in tighter, making Ne the smallest, not largest.

distractors.answer: F⁻ is the largest because fluorine is the most electronegative
distractors.explanation: Electronegativity does not determine ionic size. O²⁻ is largest due to having fewer protons per electron.

toLevel5.question: A student claims: 'Cations are always smaller than anions.' Evaluate this statement.
toLevel5.correct: This is generally true when comparing ions of similar period elements, but not universally true
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Cations lose electrons (shrinking) while anions gain them (expanding). However, a large cation like Cs⁺ is larger than a small anion like F⁻.

distractors.answer: The statement is always true without exception
distractors.explanation: Large cations (e.g., Cs⁺) can be bigger than small anions (e.g., F⁻).

distractors.answer: The statement is always false; cations are always larger
distractors.explanation: In most cases, cations are smaller than anions of nearby elements.

distractors.answer: Size has nothing to do with whether an ion is a cation or anion
distractors.explanation: Electron loss (cations) and gain (anions) directly affect ionic radius.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the sentence about isoelectronic species.
toLevel5.sentence: Na⁺, Mg²⁺, and Al³⁺ are all isoelectronic with {{blank:1}}, but Al³⁺ is the {{blank:2}} because it has the most protons pulling on the same number of electrons.

blanks.correctExplanation: All three ions have 10 electrons, the same as neon (2, 8).

distractors.explanation: Argon has 18 electrons. These ions all have 10 electrons, matching neon.
Helium has 2 electrons. These ions have 10 electrons, matching neon.

blanks.correctExplanation: Al³⁺ has 13 protons pulling on 10 electrons, giving the strongest pull and smallest radius.

distractors.explanation: More protons per electron means stronger attraction and a smaller ion, not larger.
The question is about size. Al³⁺ has the most protons, making it the smallest.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the sentence about variable oxidation states.
toLevel5.sentence: Transition metals can form ions with {{blank:1}} charges because electrons can be lost from both the outer s and inner {{blank:2}} subshells.

blanks.correctExplanation: Transition metals can lose different numbers of electrons, forming ions with different charges.

distractors.explanation: Main group metals have fixed charges. Transition metals have variable charges.
Transition metals form positive ions (cations), not negative ions.

blanks.correctExplanation: Transition metals have electrons in d-orbitals that can also be lost during ion formation.

distractors.explanation: While p-orbitals exist, the key feature of transition metals is their d-orbitals.
f-orbitals are relevant to lanthanides and actinides, not typical transition metals.
